page.title: 06THE FLORA
page.content: The small fields are separated by dry stone walls, which have weathered black and are covered with moss and lichen. In the fields there are lots of uncultivated grasses such as Yorkshire Fog. There are many wild flowers in the fields including buttercups, cow parsley, vetch, daisies and dandelions. There are some small hedges growing along the edges of the fields and are made up of small trees and bushes, the most common being holly, hawthorn,elderberry and dog roses. There also many flowers in these hedges, and large clumps of nettles which are the plant food for the caterpillars of such butterflies as the Small Tortoiseshell and Red Admiral. The trees are deciduous and include all the common varieties. The Elm is just starting to be affected by Dutch Elm disease.
